Graphical abstract Although Pt-based intermetallic compounds oxygen reduction catalysts have been developed rapidly and achieved many advances, the progress is sorted out and in-depth analysis in view of the existing problems. Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) are promising next-generation energy conversion devices with advantages including high energy conversion efficiency, low noise, and environmental friendliness. On the PEMFC cathode, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) relies heavily on Pt-based catalysts, where PtM x (M stands for transition metal) intermetallic compounds (IMCs) are considered the best choice to enhance the catalytic activity. However, problems such as inadequate catalytic activity, high cost, and insufficient durability, etc. still hamper its commercialization. The optimizations of the catalyst structure, the improvements in the preparation process, and the understanding of the reaction mechanism are of great value. The developments of cathodic oxygen reduction catalysts for PEMFCs will also focus on improving the catalytic activity of intermetallic compound nanoparticles, the utilization rate, and the durability of Pt. Controlling the particle size and particle/carrier interaction remain key issues for future research. The catalyst reaction mechanism, the surface changes of the nanoparticles of Pt (111) face before and after the catalytic reaction, and the targeted regulation of the adsorption strength between the IMCs and oxygen-containing intermediates adjusted by transition metals need to be investigated more specifically and directly. At the application level, the expression of catalyst properties in the catalyst membrane electrode and reactor are the keys to the performance of PEMFCs. Therefore, researches on PEMFCs are still systematic works. This paper summarized the recent process toward the optimization of catalyst preparation, the exploration of new catalysts, and the new understanding of the mechanism. Given the reference to the development of PEMFCs, future research can start from the existing problems, solve the shortcomings of the catalyst, and promote the practical application of PEMFCs. Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Platinum PEMFCs Intermetallic compound 1 Introduction The ballooning energy demand and deterioration of the environment necessitate the energy industry to decrease the use of fossil fuels and upgrade environmentally friendly and renewable energies [1–3]. Hydrogen has been used in fuel cells and green chemical synthesis as the energy carrier and reactive material [4–6]. PEMFCs, as an efficient energy conversion unit, exhibited promising potential for hydrogen electric conversion in vehicles, large-scale electronic equipment, and stationary power supplies [7–12]. Therefore, the lifetime and catalytic activation of commercial PEMFCs depend on the catalysts of the electrodes, especially the ORR that takes place at the cathode [13–17]. For this reason, platinum group metals (PGMs) with high catalytic activity and stability in acidic environments have been used as commercial catalysts, but the inherently hindered reaction kinetics, scarcity of raw materials, and high cost limited the promotion [18–22]. If PEMFCs, especially hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, are promoted on a large scale, the demand for Pt will increase significantly, which may lead to a shortage of Pt supply. According to literature reports, the availability of platinum should be guaranteed in the medium term, i.e. 2035, if the use of platinum in all vehicles is planned, and if research and development progress and recovery rates are met, hydrogen fuel cell vehicles sales will reach the target of 20% by 2050. The recovery rate of Pt resources must also reach 90% to ensure sustainable development [23]. Although precious metals account for a relatively high proportion of fuel cell costs, the reduction of fuel cell manufacturing costs is still a systematic project. The Pt-based ORR catalyst has been optimized for the long term, there is still room for improvement in the catalytic kinetics. ORR on Pt surfaces typically follows a four-electron transfer mechanism in which oxygen molecules are sequentially reduced to water via intermediate species such as superoxide (O2 −), peroxide (O2 2−), and hydroxyl radicals (OH−). Each step in the mechanism involves the adsorption, diffusion, and reaction of oxygen species on the Pt surface. Common rate-determining steps in the ORR on Pt include the breaking of the O–O bond in oxygen molecules, the formation of OH− intermediates, and the reduction of O2 − to water [24]. The presence of active sites, such as Pt atoms with different coordination environments, plays a crucial role in enhancing the kinetics of the ORR. Moreover, the surface structure and morphology of Pt-based catalysts, including the crystallographic orientation, particle size, and surface defects, can significantly impact the ORR kinetics. In other words, Pt-based IMCs did not reach the top of the volcano curve and the optimum balance between catalyst activity and binding strength of oxygenated intermediates was not reached [25]. ORR consists of several steps and the rate-determining steps may not be the same for all Pt-based alloys. Alloying with other transition metals to tune the binding strength of oxygen-containing intermediates and controlling the nanostructure and morphology of Pt-based catalysts to optimize the exposure of active sites [26]. This brings the catalyst closer to the top of the volcanic curve. The development of high activity, longevity ORR catalyst cathode, and reducing the amount of Pt in the catalytic layer is key to promoting the practical application of the PEMFCs [27–29]. Many efforts have been made to optimize the Pt-based ORR catalysts, including but not limited to the design of the catalyst support, the synthesis of different IMCs, the adjustments of the cluster sizes, and even the regulation of the interaction between the carbon substrate and the metal clusters [30–35]. Pt-based catalyst was also optimized through synthesizing Pt metals with different morphologies, i.e., nanowires, nanotubes, exposing the lattice plane selectively, etc., to make the most of the Pt atoms and stabilize the catalytic active centers [36–43]. Different crystal surfaces exhibit varying electrochemical properties. Pt-based nanoparticles (NPs) can be synthesized in distinct morphologies, including octahedrons or cubes [44–46]. This allows for selective exposure of the surface with high activity. Moreover, Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, etc. were also introduced to improve the ORR activity and reduce cost, but these transition metals are not stable in acidic conditions [47–54]. The leaching of transition metals can lead to several detrimental effects that can affect the performance and durability of the fuel cell system. Once the transition metal has been dissolved, the crystal lattice of the IMCs is altered, resulting in a loss of catalytic activity. The dissolved transition metals can migrate to the fuel cell membrane and cause degradation of the proton-conducting polymer membrane. This can lead to membrane swelling, reduced proton conductivity, and ultimately membrane failure, affecting the overall performance of the fuel cell. For example, some transition metals can accumulate at the anode through the PEM, resulting in reduced catalytic activity. Pt clusters are prone to sintering, dissolution, and Ostwald ripening, at the same time, corrosion of the carbon supports leads to the detachment of Pt nano-particles, resulting in a sharpened decline in the ORR performance [55–61]. The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) provided references for the research on PEMFCs [62]. For the PEMFCs equipped on heavy-duty transport, the target for 2030 of the cost is $80/kW and the ultimate target is $60/kW, and the cost reduction is a systemic subject. The PGM loading before 2030, the target is ≤ 0.3 mg/cm2 peak efficiency 68% and ≤ 0.25 mg/cm2 peak efficiency 72% for the ultimate target. The lifetime of 25000 h before 2030 and eventually 30000 h. This means that under these loading conditions, after aging treatment, it is still necessary to reach 750 mW/cm2 1.5 bar air. This poses a challenge to the mass activity of the catalyst. The activity and stability of the catalyst are important during use in vehicles, long-term use, and especially the degradation during start-up and shut down, which causes corrosion of the carbon support and Oswald ripening, shedding, and agglomeration of the Pt particles. For this reason, the Accelerated Durability Test (ADT) is carried out for a minimum of 30,000 potential cycles at a voltage of 0.60–0.95 V. Therefore, the development of ORR catalysts with high efficiency and long service life is the primary task to break through the bottleneck of fuel cell commercialization [18,29,38,57]. Intermetallic compounds are characterized by well-defined stoichiometry, atomic arrangement, and controlled crystal structure. The formation of intermetallic compounds releases a lot of heat because their chemical bonds are different from the metallic bonds of alloys, and more stable [51,53,61]. Alloys primarily exhibit metallic bonding with some solid solution bonds, while intermetallic compounds can have a combination of covalent, ionic, and metallic bonds due to their ordered and specific stoichiometric structures. The ordered arrangement influences the type of chemical bonds present, such as covalent, ionic, and metallic bonds in IMCs, but the lack of strict order in the arrangement of atoms in alloys results in a more random distribution of bonding interactions, primarily metallic bonding. Alloys are characterized by metallic bonding, where electrons are delocalized throughout the material. In IMCs, the specific stoichiometry and ordered structure of the IMCs result in directional bonding interactions, such as covalent and ionic bonding, in addition to metallic bonding. The differences in chemical bonding between IMCs and alloys result from factors such as stoichiometry, crystal structure, bonding interactions, and electronic structure, which together influence the ORR property. The electronic structure, adsorption energy, extrusion, and expansion of the lattice can be controlled by adjusting the crystal structure and composition, thereby regulating catalytic activity and stability. Pt-based IMCs have shown great promise in providing long-term cyclic mass activity for the oxygen reduction reaction. Contributing to their improved performance and durability in fuel cell applications is the unique structure of these compounds with ultrathin Pt skin and sub-size scales, which are widely regarded as the future of ORR catalysts due to their exceptional activity and stability [63–65]. IMCs boast a defined alloy composition (stoichiometric ratio) and an atomically ordered crystal structure, in which atoms of varying elements have assigned locations within the cell, as opposite to random arrangement [11,66]. Therefore, the number of Pt atoms bonded to base metals is maximized, resulting in a more significant ligand effect [67,68]. In addition, the cell parameters of IMC structures are generally smaller than those of disordered alloys, resulting in more significant shrinkage stress effects [69,70]. A shift in the d-band center and a change in the electronic structure of the surface Pt can be caused by the greater lattice strain of Pt on intermetallic surfaces [71]. This change in electronic structure confers better activity and structural/chemical stability to Pt-M intermetal catalysts [72]. As the superior catalytic activity of IMC catalysts has shown, there is still room for optimization in electronic structure, synergistic effects, high surface area, structural stability, tunable composition, catalytic mechanisms, resistance to poisoning, promotion of reaction kinetics and the structure of carbon substrate. Here, we focused on recent research advanced in ORR catalysts for Pt-based IMCs in recent years. We summed up the breakthrough in reaction mechanisms and the material synthesis, followed by elucidation in structure-activity relationships, and improved strategies for catalytic performance and durability in real PEMFC applications. At last, we finally concluded with the current problems to be solved and prospects for future development. 2 Synthesis strategies and optimizations of Pt-based intermetallic compounds The aim of optimizing Pt-based IMCs is to enhance their catalytic activity and durability for ORR, reduce Pt consumption, and lower fuel cell operating and manufacturing costs. 2.1 Sub-nanometer intermetallic synthetic strategy Nanoparticles composed of intermetallic platinum alloys exhibit enhanced electronic properties and thus superior catalytic performance [11,66]. Production of tinier nanoparticles increases the ratio of surface area to volume, thereby exposing more surface atoms and adjusting the geometry of the surface structure and electrochemical surface area (ECSA). Nevertheless, the high temperatures obligatory for atomic diffusion commonly led to the expansion of these nanoparticles [73,74]. The result of this sintering process is usually a reduction in the electrochemically active area of the nanoparticles, leading to a decrease in their catalytic activity [75,76]. To better compare the size of nanoparticles obtained by different preparation methods and the advantages and disadvantages of the preparation methods, a summary has been made in Table 1 . 2.1.1 The loading methods of the precursor on the carbon substrates The process of loading the Pt and metal precursor on the carbon substrate greatly on the nanoparticle radius of the intermetallic [77–80]. Plenty of techniques had been selected, i. e. initial impregnation method, atomic layer deposition technology, chemical vapor deposition technology, freeze drying, etc [81–83]. The experiment and optimization of carbon substrates, carbon blacks, carbon nanofibers, carbon nanotubes, mesoporous carbon, carbon gels, graphene nanosheets, carbon nanospheres, and carbon dots, etc., have been adopted. When the catalyst is prepared on a large scale and used in the device, the ease of obtaining the carbon substrates and the manufacturing cost need to be considered. In PEMFCs, the stability, electrical conductivity, corrosion resistance, bonding strength with IMC nanoparticles, and the influence of pore channels on the particles should be considered. Different carbon substrates have different pore structures and different groups, which will have a great influence on the loading of Pt and also have many influences on the regulation of the loading process of Pt. The selection and optimization of carbon substrates will be discussed in detail in the following chapters. Molecular additives that contain coordination heteroatoms such as oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur, phosphorus, etc. were added during the impregnation process. Song et al. developed a small molecule-assisted synthesis of carbon-supported platinum IMCs method [84]. During the annealing, the addition of sodium thioglycolate inhibited the sintering of the nanoparticles by forming coordination bonds with platinum during the impregnation process [85,86]. The organic species then thermally converted into a heteroatom-doped carbon coating around the nanoparticles at high temperatures, thereby producing Pt-based IMCs with small size and high order [70,74]. Because the precursors cannot be precipitated at the same time when evaporatively drying, better courses needed to be attempted [87,88]. Zhang et al. developed a cost-effective method to prepare ultra-small Pt intergeneric compounds of less than 3 nm based on rGO and then synthesized rGO-supported PtMn using this method, and has a certain universal application [72]. Freeze drying, as a method of direct solvent transfer from the solid phase to the gas phase, maintains the dispersed state of the precursor in the hydrogel and preserves the three-position polypoid structure of the precursor in the hydrogel. As the solvent sublimated, unaffected by the solubility of the precursor and maintained the atomic ratio of the metal on the substrate. Lyophilization and thermal evaporation of solvents are compared by Zhang et al [72]. Well-distributed and ultra-small precursor particles are the two main issues. The particle size affects the utilization rate of Pt and the catalyst activity, which in turn affects the cost of Pt in the catalyst, and the loading methods are the basics for achieving ultra-small IMC nanoparticles. 2.1.2 Exploration of ultra-small IMCs nanoparticles To achieve the goal, lots of methods have been taken, such as the microwave-assisted method, seed-mediated co-reduction, the water/oil microemulsion method, a sacrificial template strategy, magnetron co-sputtering, microfluidic reactor synthesis, and linker molecule stabilization, etc [89–95]. Some representative methods were enumerated and discussed, hereinafter. The durability has also been improved by the formation of the carbon shell coated on top of the nanoparticles [96]. The one-pot seed-mediated approach was adopted by Liang et al [97]. First, Pt nanoparticles were prepared and the core-shell catalyst Pt@ZnO was prepared using zinc oxide as the coating material. The ZnO matrix was then coated onto the Pt NPs by thermal decomposition of Zinc acetylacetonate in the presence of tri-n-octylphosphate (TOPO) and oleoamine (OAm), followed by reduction of the Pt NPs in the presence of OAm and borane tert-butylamine (BTB). Finally, the Pt@ZnO precursor was ordered at 600 °C. TOPO played an important role that contact with Zn2+, and the disassembly of Zn precursor was released, forcing ZnO to cover the Pt NPs. For the pre-synthesis of the coating process, Pt@ZnO and assistant of TPTO, the L10-PtZn intermetallic nanoparticles less than 4 nm were achieved. It remains a challenge to achieve small-size Pt NPs even 1 nm, the high surface energy and weak interfacial interactions are still hindering. Feng et al. adopted a strategy of pre-loading high-density monatomic seeds onto a carbon substrate and then loading high-density cobalt monatomic seeds onto the nitrogen-doped carbon substrate. The nanoparticles were fixed with a single atom as a nail, which weakened the aggregation effect and controlled the size of the nanoparticles [98]. By adjusting the density of cobalt atoms on the nitrogen-doped carbon precursor, the size of the nanoparticles was influenced. For the same amount of the Pt precursors, the size of the NPs formed on the precursors with more Co single atoms was smaller, correlated with higher utilization of Pt atoms, and better ORR catalytic activity. The MnN4 structure, formed by loading single Mn atoms onto the carbon substrates, was homoplastically prepared by Zeng et al. [99] Because of the strong linkage between Mn in the MnN4 structure on the substrate, highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles of about 2.1 nm were obtained after the annealing process. The gas-promoted dealloying process had been adopted and Pt-based NPs and high density single atomic nickel sites ORR catalyst was synthesized by Guo et al [100]. After the Pt1.5Ni octahedral nanoparticles were synthesized by hydrothermal method on the N-doped C, Pt, and Ni atoms were dealloyed and Ni atoms were detached and captured by the nearby defect sites on the carbon substrate for ammonia and heat generation. Abundant Ni single sites had been located closely near the Pt1.5Ni1− x nanoparticles. The single atom of Ni and nanoparticle produced a synergistic reaction, O2 adsorbed on the Ni atom after the reaction was transferred to the adjacent nanoparticle to complete the further reaction [100–102]. The core-shell structure had been introduced to constrain the over growth of the catalysts [46]. Zhu et al. coated SiO2 shell on the ZIF-67, dissolved the shell and achieved PtCo NPs of 2.61 nm, making the most utilization of Pt [103]. Zhao et al. coated graphene on the PtCo nanocatalysts as PtCo@Gnp [104]. A scalable method through the microwave-assisted reduction by polyols has been taken up and sub-2 nm nanoparticles have been achieved by Duan et al [105]. The annealing time was even reduced to 5 min at one point, which ensured the formation of nanoclusters and prevented the growth of nanocluster size. Although the scalable microwave-assisted polyol reduction annealing route has not yet been used to synthesize the IMCs, but prospective in the future [87,106,107]. Many efforts have been taken to achieve ultra-small IMC nanoparticles, including the usage of the anchoring effect, inert layer coating, control of the ordering temperature, etc. Efforts still need to be taken to bring forth preparation methods that not only have promotion for the obtaining of small-size nanoparticles but also promote catalyst stability and stability. 2.2 Mechanism of the intermetallic ordering process 2.2.1 Attenuation of the energetic barrier before alloying The energetic barrier has been an obstacle to obtaining IMCs with both high degree of order and small structure. The process from a disordered phase to an ordered phase is thermodynamically driven and is determined by the temperature that forces the atoms to migrate [110,111]. However, high temperatures can also cause the NPs to migrate and aggregate, forming larger particles. To bate the bond strength and kinetic barrier, Feng et al. noticed the effect of H adsorbed on the binding energy, regulating and controlling the H2 contents and temperatures in the annealing process [112]. Pt3 nanoclusters deposit on the Fe-N5-C, and the interaction force of Pt–H is stronger than that of N–H, so that H is adsorbed on Pt, which weakens the Pt–Pt and Fe–N bonding, and reduces the kinetic barrier of alloying, as shown in Fig. 1 (a) [112]. This leads to the bonding of H on Pt, which weakens the interaction between Pt–Pt and Fe–N bonds and reduces the barrier to alloy formation. The alloying process can be shifted to lower temperatures, achieved Pt NPs with an order of less than 2 nm. As shown in Fig. 1(b), the process of forming PtCo IMCs nanoparticles by single atom Co migrated and aggregated into formed Pt NPs, Co-ZIF-8 was first synthesized with single Co atoms as nodes, then carbonized and loaded with Pt nanoparticles. During the alloying stage, the Co atoms were reduced and migrated into the Pt nanoparticles, ordering and forming IMCs. Another method is to synthetic Pt-Au alloy nanoparticles in polyol, coated CoO on the nanoparticles forming a core-shell structure, the whole particles anneal and forming IMCs, seeing in Fig. 1(c). The Joule heating can achieve short-term heating and cooling, and is considered to be a highly efficient annealing method for synthesizing IMCs in a short period. This rapid thermal processing to higher temperatures allows the atoms to move more freely and rearrange into a more ordered state, lowering the energy barrier for the ordering transition. Encouraged nucleation and growth processes within the material, resulting in the formation of ordered intermetallic structures. Increased atomic mobility at elevated temperatures facilitates nucleation and subsequent growth of ordered domains, helping to lower the ordering energy barrier. The emerging periodic carbothermal shock (PCTS) through the Joule heater synthesized L10/L12 type Pt-Mn IMCs showed the small size and order by Yan et al, the process shown in Fig. 2 (a) [53]. With the Joule heating, the NPs of the IMCs are not only well defined and the particle size controllable, but they are also economical in terms of time and energy. Joule heating involves the application of an electric current to the material, which generates heat through the Joule effect. This rapid heating leads to an increase in temperature within the material, which promotes the atomic rearrangement necessary for the transition from a disordered to an ordered intermetallic structure. The new arrangement of the precursor weight is ordered to form the required structure, as the Joule heating creates numerous vacancies when heated rapidly. Cui et al. found through DFT that the lower electron cloud density caused by vacancy and the lower activation energy (0.67 eV) of the Pd-vacancy mediated diffusion pathway compared to non-vacancy diffusion (i.e. ring diffusion, 3.96 eV) significantly promote the ordered process of L12-Pd3Pb nanocrystals. In contrast, the average intermetallic particle size was smaller in conventional furnace annealing at 1273 K, where heating was slow and the annealing time was longer [115]. The Joule heating equipment is shown in Fig. 2(b, c). The temperature change process was recorded in Fig. 2(d, e). From Fig. 2(f–i), the order level is related to the number and temperature of carbothermic shocks, as the number increases, the characteristic peaks of the superlattice become visible and stronger. However, because the formation energy of L12-Pt3Mn is −0.354 eV atom−1, which is lower than the −0.346 eV atom−1 of L10-PtMn, L10-PtMn can gradually transform into the more stable L12-Pt3Mn phase as the temperature increases. The crystalline phase was made more stable by the higher temperature or more cycles of carbothermal shocks. The emerging periodic carbothermal shock obtained 4.48 nm of L12-Pt3Mn compared to the conventional furnace annealing of the average particle size of ∼12 nm. During the intermetallic ordering, the energy barrier of the precursor forming alloy is reduced, the chemical bond between the precursor is weakened, and the time and temperature of the order are reduced to obtain ultra-small intermetallic compound nanoparticles. The migration and aggregation of particles will occur at the same time. Reducing the energy barrier to reduce the ordering temperature can reduce the agglomeration of particles and thermal shock, and shortening the high-temperature time indicates that time and temperature determine the agglomeration of particles. 2.2.2 Phase diagrams and the intermetallic ordering process Phase diagrams are important bases that describe the process and state during the liquefaction and solidification, the ordering process shown in Fig. 3 (a), in addition, the content and the element-metal ratio of the alloy can be inquired at a certain temperature. Zeng et al. used the metal phase diagrams and in situ high-temperature X-ray diffraction (HT-XRD) to study the conversion process of a carbon-supported Pt IMC catalyst under high-temperature annealing conditions in Fig. 3 [116]. The phase-transition-temperature and alloying/ordering stages were identified with the help of the phase diagrams in Fig. 3(b–d). In the upper part of the phase diagrams, the metal is in a high-temperature melting state. As the temperature decreases, the melt begins to precipitate solid Pt and Fe, Co, and Ni to form a binary mixture [120–122]. As it cooled further, reaching the edge of the charge, an ordered L10 intermetallic phase began to form. The primary requirement for the formation of IMCs is that after the precursor is reduced, a high temperature is reached to break the ordered energy barrier so that the precursor atoms can begin to move. Through the phase diagrams, separated the annealing protocol designing a program was adopted that ordering energy barrier was quickly broken through at a higher temperature and the ordering process of atomic migration was completed at a lower temperature. The HT-XRD results shown in Fig. 3(e–g) can be observed that a broad diffraction peak around 41° arose when the PtFe alloy experienced temperature at 300 °C, corresponding to the (111) face of the PtFe. The weak diffraction peak at around 33° attributed to the superlattice peak of (110), which means the formation of PtFe IMCs and the ordering process occurs. However, the superlattice peaks of PtCo IMCs appeared at 800 °C during the cooling program (Fig. 3h–j), and unobserved PtNi in the whole temperature-changing process. For the fact that the annealing temperature of PtNi was below the phase-transition-temperature, and was not enough to break the kinetic energy barriers of atom ordering so the process of the disorder-to-order transition was hard to be occurred. A method of separation, in breaking through the energy barrier and ordering occurs in different stages respectively, had been come up, and ORR catalysts of high order and small size IMCs were prepared [117–119]. For more complex Pt-Sn bulk phase diagrams, different proportions of Pt and Sn precursors have been used to study the ordering process. Different proportions of precursors form different intermetallic compounds and have different melting points. DeSario et al. investigated the effect of temperature and composition on the ordering temperature of intermetallic compounds [123]. Due to the addition of strong reducing agents, like LiBHEt3 or KBHEt3, PtSn forms ordered IMC nanoparticles at room temperature, which reduces the randomness of mixing of the two metals in solution. The Pt3Sn NPs were annealed at 200 °C and entered the cubic structure. As an important basis for studying the formation of alloys, the phase diagram plays an indispensable role in studying the melting state and ordering process of IMCs. Previous reports have optimized the ordering process based on the phase diagram and explored the energy barrier-breaking temperature and the ordering temperature. However, there is still much to be explored in the future regarding the temperature of the ordering process. 2.2.3 Ordering degree-dependent performance The ordering degree of the Pt IMCs determined the performance, not only the activity but also the durability [124,125]. Song et al. prepared a range of 3–4 nm PtFe IMC catalysts with the ordering degree in a wide range of 10%–70% [126]. As a quantitative evaluation to calculate the degree of order, the ratio S(110)/S(111) + S(200) + S(002), which is the sum of the integrated area of the (110) sub-peak and the areas of the (111), (200), and (002) sub-peaks, was used in the XRD patterns. Particles with the ordering degree of 74.3%, 34.7%, and 12.4% were evaluated. The interfacial area of PtFe with the ordering degree of 74.3% is 2.211 A, which is close to the 2.192 A of standard PtFe. The interfacial area of the PtFe with 34.7% and 12.4% ordering degree is 2.227 and 2.236 A respectively, indicating greater lattice shrinkage in the PtFe with 74.3%. Durability and catalytic activity show the same result, which can be attributed to the compressive strain effect and the more stable thermodynamic IMC structure compared to disordered alloys, depending on the degree of order and lattice compression regulation [103,127–129]. The mechanism of Pt-based ORR catalyst is still promising for the future. The changes of Pt in the catalyst during the reaction remain to be analyzed, and the changes of Pt and the coordination environment during the adsorption reaction of oxygen-containing intermediate species remain to be analyzed, which requires more in-depth analysis and in situ spectroscopic and spectral evidence. The process of crystal lattice changed during the reaction and the reasons for the change remain to be elucidated. The change of the crystal surface of Pt (111) during and after the reaction remains to be revealed. In the process of studying the catalyst reaction mechanism, machine learning, statistics, simulation, and other means will also be more useful for the development of PEMFC. Based on the above analysis, it is important to design catalysts with higher activity and better stability to promote the development of Pt-based ORR catalysts. 2.3 Interaction between carbon supports and nanoparticles The realization of the transition from disorder to IMC has to overcome the barrier of the kinetic energy of the atomic order and high temperatures are needed. The interaction between the carbon supports and the nanoparticles is determined to allow the nanoparticles to migrate and aggregate so that the optimizations of the carbon supports can be anticipated. 2.3.1 Exploration and optimization of the carbon supports The nanoparticles of IMCs are bonded to the carbon substrate by heteroatoms such as O and N. The coordination strength of these atoms and the metal atoms largely determines the electron distribution of the IMCs and the closeness of the bond between the nanoparticles and the carbon substrate, thus affecting the stability and ORR activity. Platinum IMCs were synthesized with an average particle size of less than 5 nm on porous carbon supports doped with sulfur by Yang et al. [130] Notably, the interaction between sulfur and platinum on the supports effectively prevented the sintering of the metals up to 1000 °C. In Fig. 4 (a) of the XPS spectra, a new peak appeared around 162 eV, and the sulfur 2p peak shifted toward higher binding energy, indicating the electron cloud density of Pt decreased and the electron cloud density of S increased, resulting in a higher ionic bond composition in the valence bond. The S L-edge NEXAFS (Fig. 4b), 174.3 and 182.9 eV of Pt3Co/S-C were assigned to the metal–S bond compared with P + tS2. Pt L3-edge EXAFS results in Fig. 4(c) showed the coexistence of Pt–S and Pt–Pt (Co) bonds in both Pt3Co/S-C samples. In Fig. 4(d), it can be seen that the process by which metal precursors distributed on a carbon substrate transition from dispersed single atoms or clusters to IMCs nanoclusters at 600 to 1000 °C. As the temperature increases, the aggregation of dispersed single atoms and clusters becomes more intense, and the higher the temperature, the larger the size of the IMC nanoparticles. In the process of agglomeration of nanoparticles, particles without S-rivets tend to agglomerate, while particles with S-rivets migrate and aggregate more lightly, and samples with S-rivets are difficult to aggregate further when occurs to a certain extent. Zhu et al. found that P and N codoped carbon nanosheets had a strong anchoring effect, resulting in nanoparticles with an average size of 1.3 ± 0.4 nm, the clusters formed by this size are sufficiently stable, and a Pt atomic utilization rate of up to 32.81% [131]. Fig. 4 showed the comparison of different metal atoms as anchor points attached to carbon substrates and IMCs nanoparticles was made. The dense ZnN x sites in the carbon support can not only provide a source of Zn for alloying PtZn NPs but also act as a “spatial barrier” to prevent the formation of inert PtN x sites and increase the amount of active Pt in the catalyst. In the absence of ZnN4 protection, Zn-NC-PtZn has a strong thermodynamic tendency to form PtN4. After that, during the impregnation process, the Pt source is uniformly dispersed due to the Lewis base interaction between Zn2+ and PtCl6 2− [59]. Aerogel has high porosity and low density, i.e. it is which is conducive to mass transfer, especially O2 diffusion in ORR, and is resistant to the mass transfer limit [132]. Luo et al. prepared Pt-metal/metal-N-C using aerogels loaded with carbon as the carrier. Because aerogels are interconnected through holes, the catalyst has ultra-small oxygen transmission resistance, which promotes the performance of the catalyst in fuel cells [133]. Because the aerogel contains N atoms and has a strong interaction with Pt, the NPs can be chemically anchored, reducing the aggregation of nanoparticles and leading to high-temperature stability during high-temperature annealing and durability. For the same Pt particles, replacing Fe-N-C with a pure carbon substrate significantly reduces their binding energy (the higher the negative binding energy, see in Fig. 5 (a), the stronger the nanoparticle-substrate interaction), indicating that the metal-particle-substrate interaction is stronger after doping the carbon layer with metal and nitrogen. According to the corresponding optimized structure of binding energy in Fig. 5(b), the structure of different samples, the way of binding nanoparticles with carbon substrates, and the structure of NPs are more clearly shown. From the simulation diagram in Fig. 5(c) the theoretical calculation, it can be seen that the aggregation is less likely to occur when the iron single atom is connected to the carbon substrate. Zeng et al. prepared an Mn single atom loaded at the N4 sites and then loaded Pt nanoparticles on the single atom. Mn strongly interacts with both the N4 site and Pt nanoparticles on the substrate, playing a linking role and fixing the nanoparticles [99]. After annealing at 800 °C, well-dispersed Pt NPs about 2.1 nm and ordered L12-Pt3Co nanoparticles (3.3 nm) were retained on the MnSA-NC support. Self-supported ORR catalysts are attracting increasing interest due to their higher activity, better stability, lower metal content, and higher electron transfer efficiency than supported catalysts. Liu et al. prepared alloys of Pt and various transition metals catalyst with an ultrathin holey nanotube (UHT) structure via the Kirkendall effect., with ultra-thin tube walls, and constructed a self-supporting network catalyst layer with a thickness of less than 1 µm [134]. It’s the first catalyst that reached the mass activity target and dual durability targets for load and start−stop cycles of the U.S. DOE. The 100% surface exposure and efficient mass transfer made the catalyst produce high intrinsic activity [55,135,136]. The Ostwald ripening and the aggregation problem of nanoparticles has been avoided, also the low curvature of the pipe wall gave a lower surface energy for the nanotube structure. IMCs formed by loading single non-noble metal atoms onto carbon substrates and then loading Pt play a good anchoring role, which not only prevents the movement and aggregation of particles but also reduces the fall-off and aggregation of particles during the long-term durability process, which is not only conducive to catalytic activity but also conducive to improving the durability of the catalyst. 2.3.2 Optimization of carbon substrates in practical application In PEMFCs, problems such as mass transfer, flooding, and Pt depletion limit the power density of the fuel cell, while dissolution of the carbon substrates, dissolution of base metals and Pt, shedding of IMC nanoparticles, and the increase in particle size due to Oswald ripening mostly affect the performance and lifetime of the fuel cell stack. Gong et al. modified the outer surface of the carbon support with amino group (NH2), improved the utilization rate and mass transfer of Pt in the membrane electrode, and made the ORR have excellent activity [137]. A diazonium reaction method was used to prepare the amino (–NH2)-modified carbon supports. The accessibility of PtCo nanoparticles with N as the bridge to the KB had been enhanced, resulting in high Pt utilization and low mass transport resistance. Because PtCo nanoparticles are mainly deposited on the outer surface of the carbon carrier, the utilization rate of Pt is as high as 95%, improving the accessibility of Pt, and performing well in single-cell tests of fuel cells. 2.3.3 The performance of PEMFCs in the device The activity expression of the ORR catalyst under three-electrode test conditions is very different from that under single battery and stack test conditions. The main reasons for this result are as follows. The first is the transfer of oxygen in mass transfer, which is related to the design of the flow channel, the selection of the gas diffusion layer, the diffusion in the catalytic layer, the transfer in the pores of multistage porous carbon materials, and the transfer between interfaces, all of which affect the expression of catalyst activity, the contact between the active site and oxygen, and water flooding. For the catalyst, the pore structure of the carbon supports and the amount of Pt also affect the expression of catalyst activity. In porous carbon, though the particles in the pores are conducive to improving the durability because it is not easy to suffer the toxicity of sulfonic acid and the migration and aggregation of particles in the pore, the transport of oxygen and the mass transfer resistance of protons in the pore is greater, which affects the expression of the catalyst in the high current region. The loading affects the thickness of the catalyst layer. The catalyst layer with a low load and thicker load has greater resistance to the transfer of oxygen, protons, and electrons, while the load with a high load and high density is more likely to cause particle aggregation and reduce the utilization rate of Pt during preparation and long-term operation. The design of the catalyst must also be balanced in this respect. From the membrane electrode to the stack, the optimization and exploration of the flow path design, assembly process, and so on is also a systematic project for the expression of catalyst activity, and there is still much to be explored. For the selection and optimization of catalyst carbon substrate, taking into account the interaction force between IMC nanoparticles and carbon carriers, heteroatoms N, O, S, and P are introduced and form strong coordination with nanoparticles, which reduces the fall off, movement, and aggregation of nanoparticles during the high-temperature ordering process and durability test, and maintains the small size of IMC particles. However, the introduction of heteroatoms should also take into account the problem of content, too much introduction will lead to the reduction of the conductivity of the support, increase the resistance, and reduce the performance of the membrane electrode device test. In addition to heteroatom doping, the morphology of the carbon substrate must also be considered. Although porous carbon can play a limiting role in the movement and aggregation of nanoparticles, the IMCs involved in the reaction will face a relatively large mass transfer group and the accessibility of protons transferred by naphthalene to the reaction site of the catalyst will be reduced, which will reduce the activity of the catalyst and the utilization of the reaction site. The future research and optimization of carbon supports must still be optimized and explored along the lines of high loading density, low in-plane resistivity, strong interaction with IMCs, and hydrophobicity. High loading density can reduce the thickness of the catalytic layer, the resistance of the catalyst surface to the proton exchange membrane, and the distance of the protons from the membrane to the reaction site. Importantly, the mass transport of the carbon substrate has a major impact on the expression of the catalyst in batteries and stacks, particularly at low voltage and high current levels. When doping with heteroatoms, it is necessary to consider the resistance and bonding strength with IMCs. Improving the Pt utilization rate and reducing the amount of Pt in the catalyst is always the direction of ORR catalyst research. To achieve this goal, many methods have been tried to prepare small-size IMC nanoparticles, but it is often difficult to achieve both small size and high order in the preparation process. The anchoring effect, the dispersion of precursors, and the efficient order-passing process have been tried and some progress has been made. It has been possible to prepare uniform and even about 1 nm nanoparticles and effectively improve ECSA, but for the application of catalysts, the high degree of order is also positively correlated with the activity and stability of the catalyst, while reducing the ordering temperature and ordering time to facilitate the movement and aggregation of particles, it is also necessary to consider the ordering process of the catalyst. In addition, it is still promising to learn from the research results of the catalyst ordering mechanism, optimize the ordering process, and creatively use new methods to improve the ordering efficiency. The large-scale application of PEMFCs in the future will inevitably bring some problems related to industrial production, and the efficient preparation of large-scale batches will be the direction of exploration in the practical application of future catalysts. The carbon support also has a certain resistance, and the diffusion of oxygen, proton, and water in the catalytic layer will also affect the expression of the catalyst in the device. Reducing the thickness of the catalytic layer is conducive to reducing the diffusion resistance and resistance, increasing the load of precious metals on the carbon support, and promoting the effective utilization of precious metals in the membrane electrode and reactor is also of great value for PEMFCs. 3 Metal composition of Pt intergeneric compounds IMCs with different non-Pt metal can have a significant effect on the catalytic performance of the catalyst for the ORR, leading to improved catalytic activity for ORR. Synergistic effects between Pt and the other metal can enhance the ORR kinetics and improve the overall efficiency of the catalyst. The stability of the catalyst during ORR reactions is improved, and reduce the degradation of Pt catalysts, resulting in prolonged catalytic durability. On the other hand, changing the metal component in Pt-based IMCs can modify the electronic structure of the catalyst, influencing the adsorption and activation of oxygen species, leading to optimized ORR performance and selectivity. By modifying the redox behavior, the ability of the catalyst to facilitate ORR and intermediate species can be tailored for improved ORR efficiency. The components of the IMCs are discussed and examined in the following and are presented and compared in Table 2 . 3.1 Pt-based bimetallic electrocatalyst 3.1.1 Pt-based intermetallic compounds of the main group and transition metal elements Except for the common transition metal, the elements' main group element can also form IMC with Pt. Pt-Ga IMCs nanoparticles had been exploited by Lv et al. [138]. The effects of Ga salts with different anions on the formation of PtGa intermetallic compounds were investigated. The stability of ordered mesoporous i-GaPt catalysts with the chiral atomic arrangement is 5.9 times and 3.2 times that of mesoporous i-Ga3Pt5 and commercial Pt/C catalysts, respectively. The introduction of Ga is an important addition to the Pt IMCs. Fenton reaction, H2O2 catalyzed by Co Ni, etc. producing –OH, causing the PEM/catalyst layer to degrade. Due to its relatively negative redox potential, zinc is rarely alloyed with Pt, although it is considered an antioxidant in Fenton reactions. Liang et al. prepared L10-PtZn below 4 nm, the Zn atoms adjusted the distance of Pt-Pt and the ORR catalysis activity and durability had been improved [97]. 3.1.2 Pt-based intermetallic compounds of rare earth metal As a class of metals, the rare earths metal (REM) form IMCs with Pt, which have different properties to the transition metals. However, the synthesis of Pt-REM IMCs is challenging, as the standard highly negative redox potential of rare earth metals means that the oxygen-containing species would always be present. Recent advances in rare earth IMCs with Pt are summarized below. The spin configurations of Pt had been changed for the interactions between the Gd-4f and Pt-5d orbitals of Pt2Gd [139]. The spin symmetry and electronic structures changed and then compared the adsorbed and desorbed oxygen species., promoted the ORR activity, exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.95 V, and a superior mass activity of 1.5 A mgPt − 1. For the reason that the negative formation energy of Pt-REM alloys forced the nanoparticles extremely stabilized by the stabilizer for the diffusion of REM. In the Pt-REM, there is an exponential relationship between the degree of compressive strain and the surface-specific ORR activity. Offline measurements of compressive strain applied in the Pt lattice show the highest specific ORR activity relative to the Pt block at −3% shrinkage. Campos-Roldán et al. prepared Pt6.1Nd/C and Pt7.8Nd/C catalysts, that Pt6.1Nd/C presents only the hexagonal phase of Pt5Nd, while Pt7.8Nd/C is a mixture of cubic Pt, cubic Pt2Nd and hexagonal Pt5Nd phases [140]. For Pt5Nd, the Pt atom-shell on the Nd is electron-enriched and Nd suffered electron loss, so a strongly polarized bond between Pt δ − and Nd δ + happened. 3.2 Pt-based trimetallic electrocatalysts 3.2.1 PtMN (M, N = Fe, Co, and Ni) intermetallic compounds With the vigorous development of the two-component Pt-M catalyst, the three-component type Pt-MN catalyst, in which the transition metal M and another transition metal N are partially introduced, has gradually been reported to show better performance [148]. The ORR performance was improved for the reason of the surface strain of the Pt-base alloy was optimized, the structure was stabilized, and the Pt-Pt distance was adjusted. However, the focus of catalyst regulation is to reduce the dissolution of the metal, as the addition of the second transition metal is more likely to dissolve the metal in the acid. Sun et al. prepared the Pt-Co-Ni alloy was fixed on the N/O-doped graphene catalyst [88]. The introduction of Ni into PtCo alloy resulted in a strong interaction between NPs and carbon support, which improved the ORR catalytic activity and durability of the catalysts. Ternary metal ORR catalysts were also prepared by combining Ni and Cu. The ORR activity of PtCu x Ni1− x /C showed a volcanic curve with increasing Ni content. When the atomic ratio of Cu to Ni reaches 1:1, the PtCu0⋅5Ni0.5/C shows the highest activity [149]. Since Ni and Cu jointly regulate the electron cloud density of Pt, the center of the Pt-d band moves downward relative to the Fermi level, regulating the adsorption strength of Pt to oxygen-containing intermediate species [150–152]. 3.2.2 Pt-transition metals and main group metals intermetallic compounds The main group element metals are mixed with transition metals and Pt in a certain proportion to form IMCs, which regulate the p and d orbital hybridization of Pt atoms and the interaction between Pt and other metal atoms. As a result, the adsorption strength of oxygen-containing intermediates during ORR reaction is optimized, with a reduced dissolution rate of Pt, higher catalytic activity, and stability obtained. Typically, through local charge neutralization, ion displacement, etc., the formation of directional covalent bonds in metal alloys helps to confine free electrons. Due to the decrease of Fermi edge state density, more localized valence electrons and pseudogaps are formed, which provides a higher barrier for component segregation and promotes stability. Trapping free electrons within an alloy can decrease corrosion activity and metal atom dissolution. Liu et al. noted the covalent atomic interaction and prepared the L10-Pt2CuGa ORR catalyst [133]. The formation of directed atomic covalent interactions between Pt and Ga leads to a phase transition from L11 to L10 in PtCu, reducing the strain overhang in L11-PtCu. Pt-Ga interaction has a covalent bond component, which helps to increase the vacancy formation energy of surface Pt, thereby inhibiting its long-term dissolution (Pt-Ga interaction strength is 1.6 times that of Pt-Pt). Biaxial strain induced by directional bond optimizes oxygen binding energy and enhances ORR activity. 3.2.3 Pt-based intermetallic compounds with rare earth metal The Pt (111) lattice plane can be optimized by transition metals, and outstanding ORR activity and durability have been achieved. Practical applications and numerous studies confirm the performance of Pt-M catalysts. Rare earth metals, especially the lanthanide series, have been combined with Pt to form IMCs, with surprising results. New paradigms have already been carried out and attested to the progressive performance of both transition metals and rare earth metals with Pt. Due to the fact that rare earth metals are oxygenic in solution, Gd-O dipoles have been introduced into the Pt3Ni intermetallic via a high-temperature entropy-driven process by Yang et al [127]. The problem of the exchange of sites between the surface Pt atoms and adsorbed oxygen species as the thermodynamic driving force under the conditions of the potential above 0.7 V. The atoms' dissolution and crystallization happen in Oswald ripening progress, but Severe dissolution of the outermost Pt always happens through the Pt-Pt metallic bonds crushed, accelerated by potential dynamic cycling. The growth of oxides and irreversible surface recombination, such as position exchange and insertion/extraction of O atoms into the lattice, lead to the formation of rough surfaces. For the import of Gd, the sublayer formed a Gd-O dipole in the nanoparticles, and the formation energy of Gd-O-Pt3Ni is −2.88 eV lower than Gd-Pt3Ni by 5.50 eV, proving its thermodynamically favorable. The electron density of the Gd–O binding Pt site decreased, confirming the occupation of electrons in low-energy binding orbitals is more stable and the interaction between surface Pt and O is weakened. The introduction of rare earth-oxygen-stabilized Pt3Ni catalysts for site-exchange processes is delayed due to the repulsion between subsurface and surface oxygen. 3.3 Pt-based intermetallic compounds with three or more metals High entropy solid solution alloys, structurally ordered high entropy intermetallic (HEI) particles, were developed for use in fuel cell cathode oxygen reduction catalysts. Feng et al. prepared ordered-PtIrFeCoCu HEI NPs that showed oxygen reduction catalytic activity [153]. This process produces an ultra-high active surface area by combining the properties of a high entropy alloy and an intermetallic compound. The (001) facet provides the lowest activation barrier and the best d-band center. This method expands the application of high entropy alloys by breaking the disorder characteristic of high entropy alloys and making them ordered. Wang et al. designed carbon-supported PtFeCoNiMn (with an atomic ratio of 21:20:20:20:19) HEI nanoparticles and prepared them through shock-heating and shock-cooling strategies [154]. The achieved Pt on PtFeCoNiMn exhibits a wider range of d-band center distribution range than Pt nanoparticles and the adsorption properties of O2 and intermediates were changed. The d-band center value of the transition metal atom on the surface is smaller than that of the corresponding single metal nanoparticle, which makes its electronic structure similar to Pt and makes the transition metal atom also have ORR catalytic activity. The composition of the IMCs has been determined, composed of Co, Ni, Fe, and other elements have also been extensively studied, and the lattice compression stress of Pt has also been thoroughly analyzed. The addition of the third element not only affects the crystal lattice of the metal compound, but also changes the adsorption of oxygen on the surface of the particles, and even plays a role in promoting the ordering state. Other components of the high-entropy alloy also play a role in promoting the ORR reaction. In the future, high-entropy alloys will be one of the important branches of IMCs because of their special properties. For the selection of the third element of the ternary alloy, in addition to regulating the lattice structure to adjust the activity and durability of the catalyst, you can also pay attention to the special properties of the metal, the overflow effect of oxygen, the adsorption of oxygen to change the surface oxygen coverage, etc., and then change the characteristics of the catalyst. The selection of a wide variety of metals will also be an important direction for the future optimization and exploration of catalysts. 4 ORR mechanism on the intermetallic compound 4.1 Oxygen adsorption and reaction on the catalyst surface 4.1.1 Relationship between adsorption and oxygen reduction reactivity Four-electron reduction with several intermediates is the main reaction in the ORR process, O2 (aq) + 4 H3O+ (aq) + 4e− → 6 H2O. The following basic reaction steps were simulated and quantized by the electrochemical measurement technology. Much effort has been paid to identify the possible intermediates through in situ/operator techniques. As an important addition, Wang et al., with the aid of highly accurate molecular dynamics (MD) simulation with the Interface force field (IFF). The function of the solute layer and solvent layer, the free energy of O2 binding, and the adsorption statistics of O2 on the metal surfaces were revealed [155]. Water networks on the Pt surface determined the O2 contact with the surface Fig. 6 (a), that feature corrugated water adlayers, e.g. corrugated, slightly curved, or locally concave surfaces, had weaker hydrogen bonding. The time of initial oxygen adsorption and contact with the Pt surface is related to the ORR rate, while the initial chemisorption (or elsewhere along the reaction coordinates) is the rate-determining step. Due to the high concentration of hydrated hydrogen ions at 0.1 M and the instability of transient bound oxygen, the adsorption of O2 regulates the reachability of the Pt surface and prevents the remaining water reaction sequence from being possibly faster after the slow electron transfer begins, thus preventing high surface coverage. The electrolyte competition provides additional assistance shows in Fig. 6(b). Yang et al. added rare earth metal, rare earth oxygen ion pair was produced (Fig. 6c–f), which changes the O2 adsorption on the catalyst that promotes the activity of the catalyst [127]. 4.1.2 Upgrade strategy of oxygen adsorption The Pt ECSA is the dominant factor in determining the power performance, the ECSA positively correlated with the O2 capture efficiency [109,156,157]. Under the same cathode Pt load, the larger the Pt particle size, the lower the ECSA, and the lower the utilization rate of Pt. Increasing O2 capture efficiency by downsizing Pt particles is an effective approach to improve the power performance. Pt3Co NPs of different sizes have been prepared by Feng et al., through the method of seeds of Co atoms at different concentrations on a carbon substrate, the smaller the nanoparticles are, the more efficiency O2 is captured [98]. The intrinsic spin shielding effect was used to optimize the adsorption and desorption of the oxygen species [158,159]. After the O2 is adsorbed, the d-orbitals interact with O2. The 5d-2p orbital hybridization resulted in a deep-filled bonding state and partially filled anti-bonding states. The alloying of Pt with transition metal (M) can reduce the energy level of the anti-bonding orbital and increase the intrinsic activity of Pt. The central and intermediate binding strength of the d band of Pt is reduced by ligand or strain effect. When O2 is adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts, there is an energy shift of at least 0.4 eV and the phase changes from ferromagnetic to non-ferromagnetic. During the ORR reaction, the molecule changes from a triplet to a singlet. During the spin flipping, the itinerant d-electrons and the spin-related interaction of localized do affect the ORR activity, so optimizing the spin regulation and then adjusting the electron and absorption strength for O2 and the intermediates. For the 4f orbitals are half-filled made Gd an intrinsically high spin density and a natural magnetic moment, that had been made into intermetallic and exhibited outstanding ORR activity by Zhu et al. [139] The abundant single electrons in the Gd open shell change the spin states and electron delocalization of Pt ions of Pt2Gd through orbital coupling. DFT calculations have investigated the effect of spin reconfiguration on the electronic structures that improve the intrinsic oxygen reduction performance of Pt2Gd. Fig. 7 (a) shows the electronic distributions near the Fermi level (EF) that the electronic distributions of Pt2Gd have been changed compared with Pt. The projected partial densities of states (PDOSs) of both the spin-up and spin-down states were studied seen in Fig. 7(b), slight PDOS movement in Gd-5d and Gd-4f orbitals was observed for the presence of highly symmetric states. The reduction of spin polarisation in Pt2Gd optimizes the adsorption of polarised intermediates, resulting in increased coverage of the Pt surface. For the Pt site in Pt2Gd, the symmetry of the Pt-5d orbital spin state is significantly improved. Compared to the original Pt, the total Pt-5d orbital in Pt2Gd is reduced, increasing the ability of Pt to reduce ORR, as seen in Fig. 7(c). Strong spin-polarization effects in both the 5d and 4f orbitals and reverse spin pair appeared of Gd shown in Fig. 7(d, e). For the intrinsic spin shielding effect, the process of electrocatalysis has been optimized. 4.1.3 Identification of ORR catalytic active sites Separating the adsorption, reaction, and desorption processes of O2 at different reaction sites has been an innovative goal and method to improve the reactivity of catalysts and reduce the amount of Pt in catalysts [160–162]. Catalyst design becomes more relevant when one or more of the elements of the oxygen reduction process react on non-precious metal sites. Guo et al. synthesized Pt1.5Ni1− x /Ni-N-C catalyst that contained single atom Ni and PtNi alloy [100]. As seen in Fig. 8 , the DFT calculations and schematic illustrations of Pt1.5Ni1− x /Ni-N-C and reference materials, the ORR free energy diagram of Ni-N-C, Pt1.5Ni/N-C, Pt1.5Ni1− x /Ni-N-C with distant Ni sites, close Ni sites and Pt sites. The rate determining steps (RDS) of Pt1.5Ni1− x /Ni-N-C, Pt1.5Ni/N-C, and Ni–N–C are *OH + H+ + e− → * + H2O, *O + H+ + e− → *OH, and * + O2 + H+ + e− → *OOH, respectively. The *OOH intermediate, instead of being stable at the near-Ni site, migrates to the adjacent Pt-Ni sites and decomposes to O* and *OH. The multi-site synergetic effect between the Ni-NC site and the PtNi cluster site is effective in activating oxygen molecules, thereby facilitating further reduction processes. Therefore, the catalytic efficiency of the multi-site synergistic relay reaction pathway of Pt1.5Ni1− x / Ni-N-C is higher than that of Pt1.5Ni/ N-C and Ni-N-C. Inversely, Xiao et al. combined single-atom Pt and PtFe nanoparticles [145]. The mass activity of Pt in fuel cells is 3.7 times higher than that of commercially available Pt/C. Pt-N1C3, Fe-N1C3, and PtFe@Pt, all contribute to the high performance of the ORR. During the operation of the fuel cell, PtFe@Pt forms the permanent PtFe shell on the surface, and the single atomic active site is PtFe@Pt. The further reduction of the H2O2 produced above is the primary cause of the outstanding durability of the fuel cell. Charge transfer and spillover effect are the connecting bridges for the movement of the ORR intermediates and electrons. Wang et al. implemented the above functions through ordered porous TiO2− x N supported PtCu, in which the ordered porous TiO2− x N provided oxygen-deficient and PtCu with electron-deficient [163]. The reason for the electron-deficient PtCu surface was that electrons were transformed by the electron-deficient PtCu surface. The weak adsorption of ORR intermediates on PtCu, promoted the spillover from PtCu to TiO2− x N. PtCu@TiO2− x N achieved high activity for the highly efficient renewal of the active sites in PtCu by the ORR intermediate overflowing from the PtCu surface to the adjacent TiO2− x N interface. From the in-situ Raman and in-situ IR in Fig. 9 (a–d), a voltage of 1.1 V was applied, the perchlorate ion stretched and the symmetric stretching vibration of O–Ti–O can be observed. A blue shift was observed for the O–Ti–O peak in PtCu@TiO2− x N after applying a potential of 0.85 V but disappeared when the voltage was shifted to 1.1 V. The sample without N showed almost no change. The voltage at 7.7 V, the consumption of absorbed O2, stronger OH– and H–O–H peaks, but weaker OH-peak compared to PtCu@TiO2− x N, indicates that the active site renewal process in PtCu@TiO2− x N is responsible for the spillover action. As shown in Fig. 9(e), the in-situ Raman spectra indicated that the interaction of oxygenaterd intermediates with Ti will increase Ti–O bonding energy, leading to the bue shift of the O–Ti–O peaks, resulted from the interaction of oxygenated intermediates with Ti sites in TiO2− x N. OOHads decompose into OHads at PtCu@TiO2− x N, contributing to the formation of H2O. In Fig. 9(f and g), tune the reaction path when the spillover happened. In the study of ORR mechanism, the fuzzy process, the intermediate product and the change of catalyst in the reaction process, as well as the change of energy are gradually clear. The achieved progresses have been direction the design of the catalyst. In the coming phase, the mechanism study will present a more detailed ORR reaction process by combining the latest characterisation methods, new understanding and DFT. 4.2 Lattice parameters and catalyst properties 4.2.1 Lattice compressive strain tailored Regulating the lattice compression stress of Pt IMCs is an important method for altering the catalytic activity of Pt-based ORR catalysts and their effect on O-containing intermediate species [164,165]. By adjusting the lattice compression stress of Pt IMCs, the catalytic activity can be optimized to achieve the highest oxygen adsorption energy, placing it closer to the top of the volcanic curve [166,167]. Wang et al. used the binding effect of nitrogen-doped polyvoid carbon on IMCs nanoparticles to customize the size of the nanoparticles and to determine the lattice compression strain of Pt skin by intermetallic verification [108]. By regulating the lattice compressive stress of Pt intermetallic compounds, the d-band center of Pt is regulated, which affects the adsorption performance of the catalyst on the reactive substance (O2) and changes the performance of the catalyst. When the Pt-skin is composed of a single layer of Pt atoms, L12-Pt3Co applies an appropriate compressive stress to the Pt-skin, giving the catalyst a remarkable performance. To improve the contraction strain of the Pt3M intermetallic compounds, a series of ultra-small intergeneric compound nanoparticles of Pt were synthesized by Cheng et al [142]. Pt-based intermetallic (Pt3Co, PtCo, and Pt3Ti)–Pt skin core-shell catalysts with average particle size down to about 2.3 nm and ultrathin Pt skin with 4% contraction strain, exhibited excellent mass activity and cycle stability. Higher lattice pressure is positively correlated with high-quality activity and cycle stability. 4.2.2 Effect of third element metal incorporation on lattice parameters Optimizing the adsorption and desorption of oxygenated intermediates through lattice stress control is a practical and effective method [168,169]. By doping atoms of other radii in the lattice to form ordered intermetallic compounds, the cell parameters of the lattice can be effectively regulated, the compressive stress of the cell can be optimized and the length of the Pt–Pt bond can be adjusted to alter the catalytic activity. In response to the adjustment of the compressive stress in the lattice, Liu et al. prepared intermetallic compounds of Pt2CuGa [146]. The activity of L10-Pt2CuGa/C is the best regulated. In the XANES spectra in Fig. 10 (a), the valence state of Pt was consistent with the less oxidized state shown in L10-Pt2CuGa/C, indicating the existence of electron transfer between Ga and Pt. The Extended X-ray Absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra in Fig. 10(b) show the Pt-Pt bond length. The relationship between mass activity and dPt–Pt in Cu and Ga systems containing different proportions of Pt intergroup compounds has been calculated by DFT, showing a volcanic curve in Fig. 10(c).The Pt–Pt bond length in L10-Pt2CuGa/C (2.729 Å) is shorter than that of Pt foil (2.762 Å) and longer than that of L11-PtCu/C (2.702 Å), resulting in the release of overstrain in L10-Pt2CuGa than in L11-PtCu, see in Fig. 10(d). The vacancy formation energy of the surface Pt atoms was compared in Fig. 10(e), increased from 0.98 eV on Pt (111) to 1.28 eV on L10-Pt2CuGa NPs, and the structural stability and solubility resistance were improved. The electron localization function analysis and the differential charge density iso-surfaces have been carried out to compare the weathering introduction of Ga exhibits in Fig. 10(f). Charge accumulation was observed between the Pt and Ga atoms on the surface, i.e. formation of the Pt-Ga covalent bonds, but not of the Pt–Cu and Cu–Ga bonds. Compared with Pt–Pt, the interaction of Pt–Ga is 1.6 times stronger in L10-Pt2CuGa, and Pt–Cu is also stronger than that in L11-PtCu. The compressive strain caused by the addition of Ga optimized the interaction, adjusting the adsorption energy, increasing the activity, and reducing the dissolution of the metal due to the strong covalency [170,171]. 4.3 In-situ characterizations and theoretical calculations In-situ characterization and theoretical calculations can provide valuable insights into the design and optimization of Pt-based ORR catalysts. The reaction mechanism and the reaction process of the catalyst were strongly verified. 4.3.1 In-situ characterizations In situ characterizations play an increasingly important role in the field of catalysis and are widely used to study the chemical state and morphological changes of Pt-based catalysts in ORR. These techniques can provide valuable insights into catalytic processes and help to understand the structure-activity relationship of Pt-based ORR catalysts. A large number of in situ characterization techniques, such as in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), in situ Raman spectroscopy, in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM), etc., have been developed and applied to study the electrocatalytic mechanism, which can provide rich information [172,173]. These include, but are not limited to, local coordination, real-time vibrational information during the reaction, degradation mechanism, reaction intermediates, and morphological evolution. The degradation mechanism of supported Pt nanocatalysts in proton exchange membrane fuel cells has been studied using liquid cell transmission electron microscopy in Fig. 11 by Impagnatiello et al [172]. The mechanism of surface area loss of supported Pt NPs was monitored in real-time under cyclic voltammetry by energy filtering transmission electron microscopy (EFTEM) coupling. Fig. 11(a–d) shows 0, 150, and 200 CVs from left to right in the same color. At 150 CVs, the interface separating Pt/C and electrolyte was essentially unchanged. At 200 CVs, holes appear at the carbon substrates boundary in Fig. 11(b) and corrosion occurs, which is related to the shedding of Pt particles. Fig. 11(c) shows the aggregation of particles. In Fig. 11(d), it is observed that particles aggregate to form larger particles. The degradation mechanism of the region in Fig. 11(e) is shown in Fig. 11(f–g). The dissolution and movement of particles into the electrolyte are observed in Fig. 11(f and g). The precipitation of Pt particles was observed in Fig. 11(h). The above provides a more in-depth understanding of the degradation mechanism of Pt NPs under operating conditions. The diagram of the test cell in situ XAS is shown in Fig. 11(i–l). In situ, XAS reveals the progressive evolution of the electronic structure of metal clusters, which is both potential-dependent and strongly current-dependent. The diagram of the test cell in situ XAS is shown in Fig. 11(i). Fig. 11(j) shows the Pt L3-edge XANES normalized absorbance spectrum μ(E) showing potential and O2 effects on the white line. Δμ(E) = μ V(E) −μ V0(E), when under different atmospheres and potential 400–1200 mV. The area of Pt L3 is proportional to the density of the unoccupied Pt d states and can therefore be used to estimate the charge on Pt. Fig. 11(k) shows the relative change of the oxidation state. Fig. 11(l) shows that the oxidation degree of Pt decreases with the increase of potential [174]. Smooth transitions with the increase of potential between platinum surfaces with different oxygen activities can be seen. In situ XAS directly observed the Pt–O bond changes under different potentials and atmospheres. In situ Raman spectroscopy was used to evaluate the effect of different order degrees on ORR. The key role of order degree of bimetallic IMCs is revealed by in-situ Raman spectroscopy by Chen et al. [9] Therefor, IMCs with different degrees of order were synthesized. Two different types of *OH were observed on ordered and disordered structures, and ordered sites had a lower affinity for *OH and were more favorable for ORR. HT-XRD in Fig. 3(e–g) was used to determine the change in order degree of intermetallic compounds during the heating process by Zeng et al. [116] A new scheme for the alloying process of the load IMCs has been designed. The in-situ technique is of great importance for the analysis of catalyst and intermediate species at different locations. The state of poisoning and adsorption during the catalytic reaction has also been analyzed. The crystal structure and electronic structure of IMCs during synthesis have been studied. As well as changes in the structure and composition of carbon substrates and NPs during the aging process of long-term use, they lay the foundation for revealing each link in the process and providing direct evidence. 4.3.2 Theoretical calculations To gain a fundamental understanding of the ORR on Pt-based catalysts and to guide the design of more active and durable materials for fuel cell applications, theoretical calculations, in particular DFT, have been extensively used. DFT has been used to study the ORR mechanism on low-index Pt (hkl) surfaces, which helps to understand the fundamental processes involved. To guide the design of more active catalysts, the relationships between ORR performance and the structural and electronic properties of Pt-based electrocatalysts are defined. The theory will help to elucidate links between ORR performance and structural features of Pt ORR nanocatalysts, including particle size, composition, and morphologies. Theoretical insights can reveal the relationships between the ORR performance and the structural features of Pt ORR catalysts, such as particle size, composition, and morphology, and elucidate the role of factors such as strain and ligand effects. Using density functional theory calculations, Quan et al. studied carbon-loaded Pt from single atoms to nanoparticles to bulk seen in Fig. 12 (a) [175]. The ORR overpotential of the Pt-based catalyst increases as the size of the catalyst increases to the nanoparticle scale or decreases to the single atom scale, and the lowest ORR overpotential of the Pt38 cluster that catans 38 atoms about 1 nm in one NP is 0.46 V. The mechanism of ORR on Pt described in Fig. 12(b). The Gibbs free energy diagram for ORR was caculated on PtC4 single atom, Pt38 cluster and Pt111 seeing in Fig. 12(c). The free energy of forming *OOH species catalysted on Pt38 is much lower than that, the rate determined step, on Pt111 and PtC4. Differently, the the rate determined step of Pt38 is the final step, the hydrogenation process of *OH. So that, different surface structures of Pt have different ORR activities, and the possessed the highest ORR activity. The calculation results of the relationship between ΔG *O, ΔG *OH, and ΔG *OOH was shown in Fig. 12(d), ΔG *OH and ΔG *O indicated a linear scaling relation, analogously with the relation between ΔG *OOH and ΔG *OH. Result in the ORR active is expressed by O*. It was confirmed that the intermediate material anchored to the Pt38 cluster has the appropriate binding energy and is at the top of the volcano curve by establishing a volcano curve, in Fig. 12(e), relationship between the ORR overpotential and the binding energy of O* (ΔE O*). The optimal size of Pt nanoparticles obtained by theoretical calculation is about 1 nm nanoparticles containing 38 Pt atoms. In the structure of L10 IMCs, the Pt and M atomic layers are arranged alternately along the C axis and parallel to the A and B axes, which facilitates the weakening of excessive compression. Taking L10-PtFe as an example, the calculation shows that the binding energy of Pt–O is 0.23 eV and that of the disordered alloy is 0.26 eV. The Pt–O binding energy of the former is closer to the theoretical optimum value of 0.2 eV, indicating that the d-band center of the former is slightly increased and the adsorption of Pt by the intermediates is relatively enhanced [176]. The Pt–O binding energies of ordered Pt3Co and disordered Pt3Co were 0.259 and 0.278 eV, respectively, indicating that L12-Pt3Co could effectively inhibit over-compression of d-band caused by alloying [177]. The data provided by the DFT provides valuable guidance for the selection of the most suitable IMC arrangement type and transition metal in ORR reactions. It also proves the fundamental reason why the ORR activity of IMCs is better than that of disordered alloys. Overall, the search results show that DFT has been extensively used for atomic-level understanding, design guidance, and performance evaluation of Pt-based ORR catalysts as well as other non-Pt-based ORR catalysts to improve their efficiency and practical applications in fuel cells. 5 Conclusion and perspectives Significant progress has been made in recent years in optimizing and developing PEMFC cathodic ORR catalysts. The load on the electrodes has been reduced from the milligram of Pt per square centimeter to tens or even a few micrograms per square centimeter. Cycle life also ranges from thousands of cycles to the 30,000 cycles required by ADT, and some catalysts can achieve cycle life above 100,000 cycles. In this paper, the recent research progress on Pt and transition metal dissolution of Pt and transition metal nanoparticles, aggregation of nanoparticles, size control of intermetallic compounds, and carrier-nanoparticle interaction were summarized. The optimization path and possible methods of catalyst preparation are summarized, and the design principle and optimization ideas of the catalyst are refined. The method of solvent evaporation during loading, the ordering process and mechanism, and the method of barrier reduction optimize the preparation process. The carbon carrier is optimized, the seed is pre-loaded on the carrier, the pore structure of the carrier is optimized and other non-metallic atoms are doped, and the interaction between the carrier and the nanoparticles is improved to obtain ultra-small size nanoparticles. Instead of the transition metals, one or more main group elements, secondary group elements, and transition metals have also been used to form intermetallic compounds with Pt and have shown surprising activity and stability, opening up new possibilities for Pt-based catalysts. The change in content altered the dissolution, mass activity, electronic structure, and lattice compressive stress, as well as the adsorption properties of oxygen-containing intermediate species and the stability of the catalyst, and improved the activity and life of the catalyst. The catalytic process and reaction mechanism of ORR were also supplemented. This brings the intermetallic ORR catalyst a step closer to commercial application with further improvements in operating cost and lifetime. Given the problems still existing in the current stage of Pt intergeneric compound ORR catalyst, further investigation and optimizations can be carried out in the future from the following aspects. (1) Though the particle size can be prepared down to 1 nm, the improvement in the utilization of Pt is still worthwhile. The cost of the precious metal is still a large proportion.
