To optimize and innovate the preparation process, high-order degree and small-size intermetallic compound nanoparticles were obtained by changing the loading and ordering process to obtain the best ORR catalyst. (2) While much effort has been made to maximize mass activity, durability is one of the critical factors for commercial application. Inhibition of Pt and transition metal dissolution, Ostwald ripening of nanoparticles, migration, and aggregation of particles are still problems limiting the durability of the catalyst. In addition, the dissolution of the carbon base and the interaction between the nanoparticles and the carbon that the nanoparticles would also affect durability. It is still an important direction to design the proper catalyst structure so that the durability of the catalyst can be greatly improved. (3) For the ordering process, the breaking of the barrier, the weakening of the binding energy to allow atoms to move and the optimization of the ordering program have attracted attention. The understanding of the ordering mechanism is still insufficient, and the influence and optimization of the cooling process on the ordering process remain to be explored. Efforts are still needed to deepen the understanding of the ordering process, innovate the ordering process, and achieve a high-efficiency and low-cost production process. (4) Clear analysis and in situ characterization are still needed to confirm the relationship and interaction between catalyst components. Direct characterization evidence is still needed for the process of catalyst changes and changes before and after the ORR reaction. It has more profound significance for the direction of catalyst optimization and design. The changes in lattice compressive stress and adsorption state caused by the change in the electronic structure after the formation of intermetallic compounds between Pt atoms and other metals also need to be more clearly and regularly understood. Changes in the adsorbability of oxygen and oxygen-containing intermediates caused by changes in the structure and electronic layer of the catalyst also require more regular understanding to guide the design of future catalysts. (5) The activity parameters reported in this paper are still tested in a three-electrode system in the form of a half-cell. However, compared to RDE, there are more complex factors influencing PEMFCs. In addition to the intrinsic activity of the catalyst, it is also related to the mass transfer, hydrophilicity, and MEA preparation process of the catalyst. The performance of metal dissolution and redeposition in the durability test is also very different in PEMFCs. Therefore, the research of PEMFCs is not limited to the improvement of catalyst performance but also relates to the study of the entire fuel cell system, and each component is properly coordinated with each other to achieve optimal performance. HeyuanTian is a joint postdoctoral fellow at the University of Science and Technology of China and Dongguan University of Technology. He received his PhD from the University of Science and Technology of China in 2022. His research interests focus on platinum-based catalysts for proton exchange membrane fuel cells. Guanqun Xie received his Ph.D. from Zhejiang University of Technology in 2009. He has taught at Henan Normal University and Zhejiang Normal University. He is now a senior engineer at Dongguan University of Technology, School of Ecological Environment and Architectural Engineering. The research direction focuses on CO2 fixation and conversion, VOCs pollution control and process development. JunjieGe received her Ph.D. in physical chemistry from Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2010. She worked at University of South Carolina and University of Hawaii as a postdoc fellow for almost 5 years. She joined Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry in 2015 as a professor, where she was recruited in the Hundred Talents Program in CAS (2015). She joined University of Science and Technology of China in 2022 as a professor. Her research interests comprehend fuel cells, nanoscience, catalysis, and electrochemistry.

coredata.dc:description: Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) are promising next-generation energy conversion devices with advantages including high energy conversion efficiency, low noise, and environmental friendliness. On the PEMFC cathode, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) relies heavily on Pt-based catalysts, where PtM x (M stands for transition metal) intermetallic compounds (IMCs) are considered the best choice to enhance the catalytic activity. However, problems such as inadequate catalytic activity, high cost, and insufficient durability, etc. still hamper its commercialization. The optimizations of the catalyst structure, the improvements in the preparation process, and the understanding of the reaction mechanism are of great value. The developments of cathodic oxygen reduction catalysts for PEMFCs will also focus on improving the catalytic activity of intermetallic compound nanoparticles, the utilization rate, and the durability of Pt. Controlling the particle size and particle/carrier interaction remain key issues for future research. The catalyst reaction mechanism, the surface changes of the nanoparticles of Pt (111) face before and after the catalytic reaction, and the targeted regulation of the adsorption strength between the IMCs and oxygen-containing intermediates adjusted by transition metals need to be investigated more specifically and directly. At the application level, the expression of catalyst properties in the catalyst membrane electrode and reactor are the keys to the performance of PEMFCs. Therefore, researches on PEMFCs are still systematic works. This paper summarized the recent process toward the optimization of catalyst preparation, the exploration of new catalysts, and the new understanding of the mechanism. Given the reference to the development of PEMFCs, future research can start from the existing problems, solve the shortcomings of the catalyst, and promote the practical application of PEMFCs.
